author: Grace O'Connor - Health & Science Editor
title: Salmonella Outbreak in Cows: Global Rise & Risks
text:
“`html
The Persistent threat of Salmonella Dublin in Dairy Farming
The Persistent Threat of Salmonella Dublin in Dairy Farming Published: July 1, 2025
A Decade of Struggle Against a Resilient Pathogen A recent study from the University of Copenhagen sheds light on the ongoing economic and public health challenges posed by Salmonella Dublin , a disease affecting dairy cattle. Despite Denmark ‘s long-term eradication efforts, initiated in 2008, the bacterium continues to circulate, causing notable losses for farmers and presenting a potential risk to human health. While most associate salmonella with poultry, this specific strain poses a unique and growing threat to cattle globally.
Understanding Salmonella Dublin : A Silent Epidemic Salmonella Dublin is a notably virulent form of the bacteria, capable of causing severe illness – pneumonia and blood poisoning – in cattle, leading to ample calf and cow mortality. Globally, the prevalence of this disease is increasing. Currently, approximately 18% of cattle herds in the united States are infected, a figure that rises dramatically to around 60%
